SENT.plain: Previously, the authors reported that objective pulsatile tinnitus can be the major or only manifestation of benign intracranial hypertension
This report updates the authors' experience with 31 patients managed over the past 7 years
Benign intracranial hypertension should be suspected in all patients with pulsatile-objective tinnitus, especially when the patient is a young, obese female with headaches and/or visual disturbances
Papilledema and small ventricles or an empty sella on computerized tomography are almost diagnostic
The diagnosis is confirmed by elevated spinal fluid pressure on lumbar puncture
In such patients, angiography is not indicated
Furosemide and acetazolamide are very effective
Ligation of the internal jugular vein is contraindicated
